text: It's an interesting question: The tenets of classical liberalism remain very attractive to many voters but the 'leaders' associated with it have tended to be politically unpalatable or out of step with the moment . . .
author: PhilipTerzian

text: Very few people have described me as the sort of person with whom they'd want to have a beer. But in my defense, saying that classical liberalism hasn't had a great leader since Gladstone isn't the same as saying classical liberalism is passe.
author: PhilipTerzian

text: Mr Packer may not have been alive to know that the story dominated the news for months on end. There was even a conspiracy-theory TV miniseries (CBS) with the same title as his a few years later. (And of course, the murders ended with the arrest of the murderer, Wayne Williams.)

text: Memo to @WhipClyburn: Among other things, you need to study a little more carefully. Adolf Hitler was not 'elected chancellor of Germany' (1933). He was appointed by the German president, who had defeated Hitler in the 1932 presidential election.

BEGIN TO HEAL?
I shouldn't have to remind a onetime @Harvard faculty member that a civil war was fought in the United States to end slavery (1861-65, 600,000+ dead) and a Great Society was enacted (1965-68) for related purposes which has thus far cost an estimated $22 trillion.

text:
QUESTION FOR TWITTERVERSE
My beloved SmartCar is now 11 yrs old and I realize that I must (sadly) bow to the inevitable someday. Unfortunately, new SmartCars are electric so I'm pondering alternatives/equivalents: Mini, Chevy Spark, Fiat, Yaris -- any advice or vehement opinions?

text: There are three scandals in higher education: a) The destruction of free speech on campuses; b) The corrupt effect of big-time sports programs; c) Wealthy airheads 'bribing' their children into Yale, USC etc. Of course, the least important (c) attracts the most public attention.
author: PhilipTerzian

text: Or, for that matter, the interest of this or any government in (private) university admissions policies, no matter how irrational, dynastic, unfair, self-interested, capricious etc.  For people like Felicity or Lori, the more useful lesson here (as always) is caveat emptor . . .
